title-group.article-title: Risk Factors for Physiologic Radiolucent Lines Under the Tibial Base Plate After Osteoarthritis With Primary Computer‐Assisted Navigation TKA—A Nested Case‐Control Study

aff.institution: China‐Japan Union Hospital of Jilin University

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 The Author(s). Orthopaedic Surgery published by Tianjin Hospital and John Wiley & Sons Australia, Ltd.

license.license-p: This is an open access article under the terms of the http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/ License, which permits use and distribution in any medium, provided the original work is properly cited, the use is non‐commercial and no modifications or adaptations are made.

sec.title: Background
sec.p: Osteoarthritis (OA) is the most prevalent joint disease in the elderly population, and primary computer‐assisted navigation total knee arthroplasty (CA‐TKA) remains a critical therapeutic intervention for OA. The presence of physiologic radiolucent lines (RLLs) beneath the tibial base plate following CA‐TKA carries significant long‐term clinical implications and is regarded as a potential indicator of prosthetic loosening. However, the specific risk factors for RLL development in CA‐TKA, despite its theoretical precision advantages, remain poorly understood. This study aimed to characterize the clinical features of physiologic RLLs and identify associated risk factors.

sec.title: Methods
sec.p: A retrospective nested case‐control study was conducted using a cohort of OA patients who underwent primary CA‐TKA between January 2021 and September 2024. Physiologic RLLs were diagnosed according to the 1989 Knee Society Total Knee Arthroplasty Roentgenographic Evaluation and Scoring System. Patients with physiologic RLLs under the tibial base plate at follow‐up were assigned to the RLLs group, while controls were matched 1:1 from the cohort based on follow‐up time (±14 days). Covariates included age, gender, body mass index, smoking, alcohol consumption, hypertension, diabetes, surgical side, hospital stay duration, operative time, anesthesia type, continuous passive motion use, periprosthetic joint infection, total perioperative blood loss, preoperative/postoperative hip‐knee‐ankle angle (HKA), tibial cement mantle quality, cement penetration, and perioperative medial proximal tibial angle. Univariate and multivariate analyses were performed to identify risk factors.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The cohort comprised 407 patients, of whom 113 developed physiologic RLLs under the tibial base plate. Univariate analysis identified age, preoperative HKA, tibial cement mantle defects, and cement penetration as statistically significant risk factors (all p < 0.05). Multivariate logistic regression analysis revealed that preoperative HKA (OR = 0.919, 95% CI = 0.876–0.963, p < 0.001), tibial cement mantle defects (OR = 2.638, 95% CI = 1.043–6.668, p = 0.040), and cement penetration (OR = 0.205, 95% CI = 0.126–0.332, p < 0.001) were independent risk factors for physiologic RLLs under the tibial base plate after primary CA‐TKA in OA patients. Age was not an independent risk factor.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The overall incidence and clinical characteristics of physiologic RLLs under the tibial base plate after primary CA‐TKA were comparable to those reported for conventional TKA techniques. This nested case‐control study identified preoperative HKA, tibial cement mantle defects, and cement penetration as independent risk factors for physiologic RLLs, whereas age was not.

abstract.p: This study identifies preoperative hip‐knee‐ankle angle, cement mantle on the tibia, and cement penetration as independent risk factors for the development of radiolucent lines (RLLs) under the tibial base plate after primary computer‐assisted navigation TKA in osteoarthritis patients, providing insights into potential predictors of prosthesis loosening.

institution-wrap.institution: Department of Science and Technology of Jilin Province
Department of Finance of Jilin Province

p.mixed-citation: H.Tian, Y.Ma, J.Zhang, E.Liu, Z.Zhang, and J.Zuo, “Risk Factors for Physiologic Radiolucent Lines Under the Tibial Base Plate After Osteoarthritis With Primary Computer‐Assisted Navigation TKA—A Nested Case‐Control Study,” Orthopaedic Surgery17, no. 9 (2025): 2717–2725, 10.1111/os.70134.PMC1240486140776479

fn.p: Funding: This work was supported by the Department of Science and Technology of Jilin Province (Nos. 20230508171RC, YDZJ202201ZYTS043, YDZJ202201ZYTS076), the Department of Finance of Jilin Province (Nos. 2023SCZ89, 2022SCZ03).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Osteoarthritis (OA) represents the most prevalent joint disease in the elderly population, with approximately one‐third of individuals over 65 years of age affected by the condition [1, 2]. Epidemiological investigations have found that the prevalence of OA is gradually increasing with the aging of the population, influenced by causative factors such as age, genetics, and obesity [3]. Total knee arthroplasty (TKA) is an effective therapeutic strategy for OA patients unresponsive to pharmacological management, effectively alleviating pain, improving functional capacity, and enhancing quality of life in advanced disease [4, 5, 6].

Computer‐assisted navigation systems enabling surgeons to achieve these goals with greater precision [7]. Although computer‐assisted TKA (CA‐TKA) has a reduced probability of revision of the implant due to aseptic loosening of the prosthesis at 2 years compared with conventional non‐navigation‐assisted arthroplasty [8]. However, based on the fact that prostheses have a certain service life [9], aseptic loosening remains a core reason for postoperative TKA failure [10]. Aseptic loosening of the implant is usually preceded by the observation of radiolucent lines (RLLs) on X‐ray [11]. RLLs under the tibial base plate after TKA are radiographically permeable intervals between bone cement or implant and adjacent tibiae [12], and it is often considered to be an indicator of prosthetic loosening. Surgeons for the most part consider the presence of RLLs when assessing post‐TKA outcomes [13]. Post‐TKA tibial RLLs are clinically categorized into two distinct entities: physiological and pathological. Physiological RLLs typically present asymptomatically, whereas pathological RLLs are diagnosed when radiolucencies coexist with persistent knee pain postoperatively [12]. However, it is notable that while physiological RLLs typically do not affect patient prognosis, their long‐term implications for implant stability and subsequent progression remain incompletely understood. Meanwhile, such radiographic abnormalities still represent the necessity for refinement in CA‐TKA.

Therefore, this nested case‐control study aims to identify the risk factors for physiological RLLs under the tibial prosthesis following CA‐TKA, thereby providing guidance for optimizing surgical techniques.

This study aimed to (i) quantify the incidence and temporal progression of physiologic RLLs under the tibial baseplate following CA‐TKA, (ii) characterize the zonal distribution patterns of these RLLs on radiographic imaging, and (iii) determine through univariate and multivariate analyses whether the following parameters constitute risk factors for RLL development: demographic factors, lifestyle factors, comorbidities, surgical parameters, perioperative outcomes, prosthetic complications, alignment measures, and cementation characteristics.

sec.title: Subjects of Study
sec.p: Ethics Committee of China‐Japan Union Hospital of Jilin University approved the study (No. 2021‐KYLY‐020043). A total of 481 patients who underwent primary computer navigation‐assisted TKA for OA at our institution between January 2021 and September 2024 were selected.

The base study cohort was purified using exclusion criteria, which included (in order of application): lack of imaging follow‐up, absence of computer navigation records, ≥ 3 missing clinical data items, simultaneous bilateral knee arthroplasty, preoperative severe cardiorespiratory dysfunction, preoperative urinary tract infection, preoperative malignancy, and revision knee prosthesis. A total of 407 patients were included in the final study cohort.

sec.title: Establishment of Case and Control Groups
sec.p: This was a retrospective nested case‐control study. Imaging data obtained during patient follow‐up were assessed using the 1989 Knee Society Postoperative X‐ray Evaluation and Scoring System for TKA [14], with RLL's diagnosis as the follow‐up endpoint. All analyzed RLLs were classified as physiologic based on stability, absence of symptoms, and lack of association with subsequent prosthetic failure during the study period. The minimum follow‐up duration was 3 weeks postoperatively. The follow‐up cutoff for the study cohort was 21 October 2024, and the median follow‐up time was 62.5 (41.0–278.25) days.

Results showed that 113 individuals in the study cohort had physiologic RLLs under the tibial base plate at the first post‐TKA follow‐up, comprising the RLLs group. Controls were selected based on matching follow‐up time (±14 days), with 1:1 matching of non‐RLLs patients from the cohort. The final analysis included 113 cases in the RLLs group and 113 matched controls.

sec.title: Clinical Data Collection
sec.p: Clinical information for study cases was collected by querying the clinical information system. Data collected included age, gender, body mass index (BMI), smoking status, alcohol consumption, hypertension, diabetes, surgical side, hospital stay duration, operative time, anesthesia type, continuous passive motion (CPM) use, periprosthetic joint infection (PJI), total perioperative blood loss, preoperative/postoperative hip‐knee‐ankle angle (HKA), tibial cement mantle quality, cement penetration, and perioperative medial proximal tibial angle (MPTA).

sec.title: Imaging Data Collection
sec.p: Two orthopedic residents reviewed study imaging data via the Picture Archiving and Communication System (PACS), performed imaging measurements, and recorded data.

The average thickness of the tibial implant cement mantle was measured according to the 1989 Knee Society Total Knee Arthroplasty Roentgenographic Evaluation and Scoring System [14]. Four regions were assessed on the anteroposterior (AP) knee view, and two regions on the lateral (LAT) view, with average thickness calculated across all six regions. Cement mantle thickness was categorized into tibial cement mantle (thickness from the prosthesis lower edge to the cancellous bone upper edge) and cement penetration (thickness of cement infiltrating within cancellous bone) (Figure 1).

caption.p: Radiological measurement, (A) Hip‐knee‐ankle angle and medial proximal tibial angle; (B and C) Radiographic evaluation of RLLs according to the “1989 The Knee Society Total Knee Arthroplasty Roentgenographic Evaluation and Scoring System” [14], the red line is cement mantle on tibia and the blue line is cement penetration.

sec.p: HKA was defined as the angle between the femoral mechanical axis and tibial mechanical axis on full‐length weight‐bearing lower limb radiographs, with a standardized value of 180° (Figure 1). MPTA was defined as the medial angle between the tibial mechanical/anatomic axis and the proximal tibial joint line, with a standardized value of 90° (Figure 1).

sec.title: Diagnosis and Partitioning of the Physiologic RLLs Under the Tibial Base Plate
sec.p: Diagnosis of physiologic RLLs was independently assessed by two orthopedic residents via the PACS system using the 1989 Knee Society Postoperative X‐ray Evaluation and Scoring System for TKA, based on follow‐up imaging after computer‐assisted TKA in the study cohort. The tibial base plate was partitioned according to the Knee Society zones: in the AP view, zones 1 and 2 represent the medial tibial plateau, and zones 3 and 4 represent the lateral tibial plateau; in the LAT view, zone 1 represents the anterior aspect and zone 2 represents the posterior aspect of the tibial base plate (Figure 2). The specific regions of physiologic RLLs were identified, and in cases of diagnostic discrepancy, a third senior orthopedic surgeon rendered the final diagnosis.

caption.p: Incidence of RLLs in the AP (A) and the LAT (B) tibial radiograph measured according to the “1989 The Knee Society Total Knee Arthroplasty Roentgenographic Evaluation and Scoring System”.

sec.title: Perioperative Management and Postoperative Follow‐Up
sec.p: All TKA procedures were performed using the OrthoPilot computerized infrared navigation system. Intraoperative tourniquets were used, surgeries were conducted via medial parapatellar incisions with cemented total knee prostheses, and elastic bandages were applied at surgery completion to reduce lower limb deep vein thrombosis risk. Postoperative antibiotics were routinely administered for infection prophylaxis. In the absence of contraindications, low‐molecular‐weight heparin sodium was initiated 6–8 h after general anesthesia or 12 h after lumbar anesthesia for deep vein thrombosis prevention, with oral rivaroxaban continued post‐discharge and routine anticoagulation maintained until 35 days postoperatively.

Full weight‐bearing of the lower limbs was permitted within 2 days postoperatively, and comprehensive lower limb functional rehabilitation programs were initiated on the first postoperative day. Patients were discharged 5–14 days postoperatively if free of serious complications, with rehabilitation continued per discharge instructions. Regular follow‐up evaluations included patient‐reported symptoms, knee joint examinations, and knee digital radiography.

sec.title: Statistical Analyses
sec.p: Normally distributed continuous variables were described as mean ± standard deviation (x¯ ± s), non‐normally distributed variables as median and interquartile range (M[P25, P75]), and categorical variables as count and percentage (n[%]). Between‐group comparisons for normally distributed variables were performed using Student's t‐test, for non‐normally distributed variables using Mann–Whitney U test, and for categorical data using chi‐square test. Variables with p < 0.05 in univariate analysis underwent multifactorial logistic regression analysis. Statistical significance was defined as p < 0.05, with all analyses conducted using SPSS 26.0 (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY, USA).

sec.title: Incidence and Temporal Characteristics of Physiologic RLLs
sec.p: Using the 1989 Knee Society Total Knee Arthroplasty Roentgenographic Evaluation and Scoring System as the evaluation criterion, the results showed that 113 of 407 patients in the study cohort exhibited physiologic RLLs under the tibial base plate at follow‐up after CA‐TKA between January 2021 and September 2024, with an overall incidence of 27.8%. The median time to physiologic RLLs occurrence was 56 (40–266) days, with 38 (33.6%) cases occurring within 3 months postoperatively, 97 (85.8%) within 1 year, and the latest RLLs detected on the 496th day of follow‐up. Except for 2 patients with RLLs who underwent revision surgery due to PJI after failed conservative treatment, the remaining patients displayed no significant abnormal clinical symptoms.

sec.title: Zonal Distribution of Physiologic RLLs
sec.p: The location of physiologic RLLs under the tibial base plate in the 113 knees of the RLLs group was shown in Figure 2. On the anteroposterior (AP) knee view, 60 (53.1%) cases of physiologic RLLs were identified in zone 2, while on the lateral (LAT) view, 29 (25.7%) cases were detected in zone 2. Additionally, physiologic RLLs were predominantly observed in the medial aspect of the tibial base plate (zones 1 and 2) on AP views, with 79 (69.9%) cases involving the medial tibial base plate.

sec.title: Baseline Patient Characteristics
sec.p: Table 1 showed the baseline characteristics of the control and RLLs groups. Gender, BMI, smoking status, alcohol consumption, hypertension, diabetes, surgical side, hospital stay duration, operative time, anesthesia type, continuous passive motion use, PJI, total perioperative blood loss, postoperative HKA, and perioperative MPTA did not differ significantly between the two groups (p > 0.05).

caption.p: Univariable and multivariate analysis of the RLLs and Control group.

tr.td: Cement mantle on the tibia, MP25P75

fn.p: Note: Bold indicates significant independent risk factors identified by multivariate analysis.
Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; CPM, continuous passive motion; HKA, hip‐knee‐ankle angle; MPTA, medial proximal tibial angle; PJI, periprosthetic joint infections.

sec.title: Significant Intergroup Differences in Univariate Analysis
sec.p: The RLLs group had a higher mean age (67.31 ± 5.13) compared to the control group (65.21 ± 6.97) (p = 0.011). The RLLs group exhibited more severe preoperative knee varus deformity, with a smaller preoperative HKA (165.39 ± 9.68) compared to the control group (170.86 ± 5.23) (p < 0.001). The median tibial cement mantle thickness in the RLLs group was 0.93 (IQR = 0.62–1.32) mm, significantly thicker than 0.84 (IQR = 0.49–1.12) mm in the control group (p = 0.002). Conversely, the median cement penetration depth was 1.32 (IQR = 0.66–2.13) mm in the RLLs group, significantly shallower than 2.39 (IQR = 1.88–3.01) mm in the control group (p < 0.001).

sec.title: Independent Risk Factors for RLL Development
sec.p: Multivariable logistic regression analysis showed that median tibial cement mantle thickness (OR = 2.638, 95% CI = 1.043–6.668, p = 0.040) was an independent risk factor positively associated with physiologic RLLs occurrence after CA‐TKA in OA patients. Preoperative HKA (OR = 0.919, 95% CI = 0.876–0.963, p < 0.001) and cement penetration depth (OR = 0.205, 95% CI = 0.126–0.332, p < 0.001) were independent risk factors negatively associated with physiologic RLLs, whereas age (OR = 1.051, 95% CI = 0.996–1.110, p = 0.070) was not (Table 1).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, patients undergoing primary CA‐TKA for end‐stage osteoarthritis were investigated. The primary aims were to quantify the incidence and temporal progression of physiologic RLLs under the tibial baseplate, characterize their zonal distribution patterns, and determine risk factors among demographic, surgical, and cementation parameters. Key findings demonstrated a 27.8% incidence of physiologic RLLs, with 85.8% occurring within 1 year and 69.9% localized medially. Multivariable analysis identified thicker tibial cement mantle as an independent risk factor, while greater preoperative hip‐knee‐ankle angle and deeper cement penetration were protective. Age, BMI, CPM use, and other demographic/surgical factors showed no significant association.

sec.title: Incidence and Temporal Patterns of RLLs
sec.p: Aseptic loosening of the implant is the most common indication for TKA revision over the past decade [15]. Following TKA, it is typically preceded by the observation of RLLs under the tibial base plate on X‐rays (Figure 3). Pathologic RLLs represent prosthetic failure, and physiological RLLs may have a connection with aseptic loosening [16, 17, 18]. In our study, the overall incidence of physiological RLLs is 27.8%. Previous studies have shown that RLLs occur most frequently beneath the tibial prosthesis in 97% of patients [12].

caption.p: Examples of radiolucent lines, (A) In AP view, RLL at the medial tibial baseplate (zone 2, red arrow); (B) In AP view, RLL at the external tibial baseplate (zone 2 and zone 4, red arrow); (C) In LAT view, RLL at the anterior tibial baseplate (zone 1, red arrow).

sec.title: Biomechanical and Anatomical Determinants of RLL Distribution
sec.p: Gait analysis indicates that biomechanically, approximately 60%–80% of the load is transmitted to the medial knee compartment during normal walking [19], resulting in a load on the medial articular surface that is 2.5 times greater than that on the lateral surface [20, 21]. In our study, RLLs develop medially in 69.9% of knee tibial prostheses. Most cemented tibial prosthesis RLLs appear in the immediate postoperative period or within 12 months [22]. In contrast, for cementless tibial prostheses, an analysis of RLLs on frontal and lateral X‐rays up to 3 years after trabecular‐metal TKA demonstrates that the frequency of RLLs in trabecular‐metal tibial prostheses is highest during the first year after TKA and then gradually decreases [23]. Additionally, 99% of RLLs are nonprogressive, and most progressive RLLs do not compromise implant fixation or stability; no patients have undergone revision surgery for aseptic loosening [12]. After TKA, RLLs are frequently observed at the epiphyseal bone/implant interface but do not necessarily indicate implant loosening. They can be interpreted as a sign of reduced epiphyseal surface fixation due to micro‐mobility of the tibial implant [24]. This aligns with our findings that physiologic RLLs occur at a relatively early stage: according to imaging follow‐up, 33.6% of RLLs in our study appear within 3 months after TKA, 85.8% within 1 year, and the latest RLLs appear on day 496 of postoperative follow‐up.

sec.title: Cement Application Techniques: Implications for RLLs and Loosening
sec.p: A disadvantage of bone cement as an adhesive is that heat released during polymerization can damage surrounding tissue, leading to thermal necrosis [25]. One of the major causes of RLLs after cemented prosthetic replacement is the thermal necrosis that occurs in the months following surgery [26]. Bone cement penetration is critical to the surgical success of TKA. Increased cement mantle has been shown to improve implant survival and stability [27], and aseptic loosening after TKA has been associated with more areas of cement penetration < 2 mm [10]. However, previous studies often define cement mantle penetration as the total thickness of bone cement beneath the prosthesis [28]. Whereas in our study, we categorized the cement mantle penetration into cement mantle on tibia, which is below the implant to the surface of the tibia, and cement penetration within the cancellous bone of the tibia. Our findings suggest that the cement mantle on tibia was significantly higher in the RLLs group than in the control group and that cement mantle on tibia is an independent risk factor for the development of tibial RLLs after primary TKA for OA. Whereas cement penetration was significantly lower in the RLLs group than in the control group, radiologic indicators of poor cement penetration were associated with subsequent aseptic loosening. This emphasizes the need for surgeons to improve their cement application techniques to reduce the risk of TKA failure [10]. When implanting tibial cemented prostheses, appropriate impact force should be used to ensure tight apposition of the tibial plateau implant to the tibia. In TKA studies with up to 10 years of follow‐up, early‐onset, nonprogressive limited RLLs are observed in 15% of patients with well‐fixed femoral prostheses and low‐wear, typically associated with preoperative sclerotic bone. In low‐wear prostheses, RLLs may arise from failure to inject cement into sclerotic bone. However, most of these radiolucent lines are nonprogressive and do not compromise implant fixation [18].

Additionally, post‐TKA RLLs occurring immediately after surgery and secondary to surgical technique are attributed to insufficient cement penetration into sclerotic bone, inadequate osteotomy, or mismatch between implant position and osteotomy [11]. Modern cementing techniques in TKA are highly standardized. High‐pressure pulse flushing, bone bed drying, tibial drilling, and application of mixed cement to both the implant and bone are mandatory steps during TKA prosthesis placement [29]. Appropriate ancillary measures are necessary to enhance cement penetration depth into bone. For example, a pulsed flushing system can clean the cancellous bone surface more effectively before cement application [30]. Compared with syringe flushing, pulse flushing significantly increases cement penetration depth [31]. Specifically, it reduces unnecessary micromovement during cement curing, prevents cement dissociation, and avoids gap formation at the metal‐cement‐bone interface.

sec.title: Computer‐Assisted TKA: RLL Incidence and Clinical Relevance
sec.p: The use of computer‐assisted navigation and robotic‐assisted arthroplasty has grown exponentially over the past decade. CA‐TKA primarily improves implant alignment accuracy [32]. Although CA‐TKA is significantly more accurate than traditional TKA in terms of lower extremity mechanical axis and prosthesis implantation position, no differences exist between the two techniques in functional outcomes, revision rates, or aseptic loosening rates [33]. In a 10‐year follow‐up, Ollivier M. et al. found no difference in survival without aseptic loosening between computer‐assisted navigation and traditional techniques 10 years after TKA [34]. While RLLs are widely considered indicators or predictors of implant loosening, the incidence of RLLs in CA‐TKA remains understudied. This study demonstrates for the first time that the early incidence of physiologic RLLs in CA‐TKA is 33.6%, generally consistent with rates reported for traditional techniques. The findings also indirectly suggest that CA‐TKA does not reduce the incidence of aseptic loosening compared with conventional TKA.

sec.title: Patient‐Specific Risk Factors for RLL Development
sec.p: In a study by Wautier D, older women with osteoporosis and younger men with significant preoperative deformities were identified as clinical risk factors for RLLs [24]. The risk factors for aseptic loosening after TKA are relatively complex, with age potentially being an important contributor. Age may interact with other factors such as bone quality, activity level, and postoperative rehabilitation. Patients with osteoporosis have a moderately increased risk of revision due to aseptic loosening within 5 years after TKA [35]. As osteoporotic fractures increase with age and osteoporosis is strongly associated with postmenopausal women, both age and female sex are recognized clinical risk factors for osteoporosis [36]. In our study, univariate analysis identified age and more severe preoperative knee varus as independent risk factors for physiologic RLLs, generally consistent with Wautier D's findings. However, gender was not significant, and age lost statistical significance in multivariable logistic regression analysis.

Excessive BMI is a well‐established risk factor for knee OA development, contributing to younger ages at the time of TKA surgical treatment [37]. Non‐morbidly obese and morbidly obese patients account for 23.2% of all TKA [38], and effective obesity control has the potential to reduce the need for TKA and associated costs [39]. Some studies suggest that increased BMI is a significant risk factor for RLLs [40]. Notably, compared with non‐obese patients, morbidly obese patients exhibit lower mean Knee Society objective and functional scores after TKA. Radiographic translucent lines are prevalent in 12%, 19%, and 14% of nonobese, obese, and morbidly obese patients, respectively, with no significant differences across obesity classifications [41]. This aligns with our finding that BMI is not a risk factor for physiologic RLLs under the tibial base plate, with no statistically significant differences observed compared to the control group. However, preoperative BMI influences joint replacement failure timing and mechanisms [42]. Morbidly obese patients have significantly lower prosthesis survival rates than obese and non‐obese patients [41]. In a subset of morbidly obese patients with severe knee OA, bariatric surgery can alleviate knee pain symptoms, potentially delaying or avoiding orthopedic intervention [43]. Therefore, we continue to recommend that higher‐BMI patients undergo appropriate weight management before TKA to optimize outcomes and reduce surgical failure rates.

sec.title: Rehabilitation Strategies and RLL Association
sec.p: CPM is a common rehabilitation modality after TKA, involving a specialized machine that passively and repetitively moves the knee through a specified range of motion [44]. However, current literature lacks conclusive scientific evidence to demonstrate short‐ or long‐term benefits of CPM, as it has no clinically significant impact on active knee flexion range, pain, function, or quality of life, and does not provide sufficient justification for routine use in TKA patients [45, 46]. Whereas the use of stirrup exercises, weight training, balance, and sensorimotor training as an adjunct to a multidisciplinary program after TKA has significant benefits [47], a proactive approach to exercise that encourages patients to participate in their rehabilitation should be the preferred option for early postoperative rehabilitation after TKA [46]. In our study, all patients underwent active rehabilitation exercises post‐TKA, with some also receiving CPM training. Notably, existing literature lacks studies on the correlation between CPM and physiologic RLLs, and our findings show that CPM was not a risk factor for early postoperative physiologic RLLs after CA‐TKA.

sec.title: Limitations and Strengths
sec.p: This study has several limitations. As a retrospective nested case‐control study, its sample size is relatively small. Additionally, as a single‐center study, most subjects were from high‐latitude regions of China, imparting geographical limitations to the findings and their clinical applicability.

Despite these limitations, this study provides the first comprehensive analysis of physiologic RLLs in CA‐TKA, uniquely quantifying incidence dynamics, spatial distribution, and cementation‐specific risk factors through a nested case‐control study, establishing actionable surgical benchmarks for TKA optimization.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This nested case‐control study identified preoperative HKA, tibial cement mantle thickness, and cement penetration depth as independent risk factors for physiologic RLLs under the tibial base plate after primary CA‐TKA in OA patients, whereas age was not. Appropriate intraoperative measures to reduce tibial cement mantle thickness and enhance cement penetration can partially mitigate the occurrence of physiologic RLLs under the tibial base plate. This approach may prolong knee implant survival, reduce the incidence of prosthetic loosening after CA‐TKA, and minimize the need for revision surgery.

sec.title: Author Contributions
sec.p: Hao Tian: conceptualization, methodology, formal analysis, writing – original draft, writing – review and editing. Yang Ma: investigation, methodology, writing – original draft. Jinrui Zhang: data curation, validation, formal analysis, writing – original draft. Enbo Liu: data curation, investigation, methodology, writing – original draft. Zhuo Zhang: data curation, investigation, formal analysis, writing – original draft. Jianlin Zuo: supervision, writing – original draft, writing – review and editing.

sec.title: Ethics Statement
sec.p: This study was approved by the Ethics Committee of China‐Japan Union Hospital of Jilin University (No. 2021‐KYLY‐020043).

sec.title: Consent
sec.p: The authors have nothing to report.

sec.title: Conflicts of Interest
sec.p: The authors declare no conflicts of interest.

sec.title: Data Availability Statement
sec.p: The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request.
